Bond mutual funds 110 — 110 —
Real estate trust funds 36 — — 36
Private debt funds 17 — — 17
Insurance contracts 2 — — 2
Debt securities 59 59 — —
Equity securities 37 37 — —
Total $307 $100 $152 $55

Fair Value Measurements at December 31, 2021
Asset Category Total Quoted Prices in Active Markets for Identical Assets (Level 1) Significant Observable Inputs (Level 2) Significant Unobservable Inputs (Level 3)
(in millions)
Cash and cash equivalents $13 $13 $— $—
Time deposits 29 — 29 —
Equity mutual funds 33 — 33 —
Bond mutual funds 216 — 216 —
Real estate trust funds 35 — — 35
Hedge funds 11 — — 11
Insurance contracts 4 — — 4
Debt securities 56 56 — —
Equity securities 41 41 — —
Total $438 $110 $278 $50
Following is a description of the valuation methodologies used for pension assets measured at fair value.
Time deposits—The fair value of fixed-maturity certificates of deposit was estimated using the rates offered for deposits of similar remaining maturities.
Equity mutual funds—The fair value of the equity mutual funds is determined by the indirect quoted market prices on regulated financial exchanges of the underlying investments included in the fund.
Bond mutual funds—The fair value of the bond mutual funds is determined by the indirect quoted market prices on regulated financial exchanges of the underlying investments included in the fund.

Real estate—The fair value of real estate properties is estimated using an annual appraisal provided by the administrator of the property investment. Management believes this is an appropriate methodology to obtain the fair value of these assets.
qa:
Question 1: What is the year-on-year growth rate of the pension plan assets from 2021 to 2022?
Answer 1: Using the formula <Year-on-year growth rate = (Value in later year - Value in earlier year) / Value in earlier year>, we know the total asset value in 2022 is $307 million and in 2021 it was $438 million, so the answer is (307-438)/438=-0.299 or -29.9%.

Question 2: What is the proportion of Level 1 assets in the total pension plan assets for the year 2022?
Answer 2: Using the formula <Proportion = Part / Whole>, we know the Level 1 assets in 2022 is $100 million and the total asset is $307 million, so the answer is 100/307=0.326 or 32.6%.

Question 3: What is the change in the value of Equity mutual funds from 2021 to 2022?
Answer 3: Using the formula <Change in value = Value in later year - Value in earlier year>, we know the value of Equity mutual funds in 2022 is $6 million and in 2021 it was $33 million, so the answer is 6-33=-27 million.

Question 4: What is the Compound Annual Growth Rate (CAGR) of the Bond mutual funds from 2020 (assuming the value was $200 million) to 2022?
Answer 4: Using the formula <CAGR = [(Value in later year / Value in earlier year) ^ (1 / Number of years) - 1], we know the value of Bond mutual funds in 2022 is $110 million and in 2020 it was $200 million, so the answer is [(110/200)^(1/2)]-1=-0.301 or -30.1%.

gpt_string:
Year Ended December 31, 2014 versus Year Ended December 31, 2013.
Our gross profit margin increased to 61.1 percent in 2014 from 60.7 percent in 2013. The increase was partially due to the deconsolidation of our Brazilian bottling operations in July 2013 as well as lower commodity costs, primarily in our North America finished goods business, and favorable geographic mix. Refer to Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information regarding the impact of the deconsolidation of our Brazilian bottling operations.
The favorable geographic mix was primarily due to growth in emerging markets. Although this shift in geographic mix has a negative impact on net operating revenues, it generally has a favorable impact on our gross profit margin due to the correlated impact it has on our product mix. The product mix in the majority of our emerging and developing markets is more heavily skewed toward our sparkling beverage products, which generally yield a higher gross profit margin compared to our still beverages and finished products.
Selling, General and Administrative Expenses.
The following table sets forth the significant components of selling, general and administrative expenses (in millions):
Year Ended December 31, | 2015 | 2014 | 2013
Stock-based compensation expense | $236 | $209 | $227
Advertising expenses | 3,976 | 3,499 | 3,266
Selling and distribution expenses | 6,025 | 6,412 | 6,419
Other operating expenses | 6,190 | 7,098 | 7,398
Selling, general and administrative expenses | $16,427 | $17,218 | $17,310

Year Ended December 31, 2015 versus Year Ended December 31, 2014.
Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased $791 million, or 5 percent. During the year ended December 31, 2015, fluctuations in foreign currency decreased selling, general and administrative expenses by 6 percent. The increase in stock-based compensation was primarily due to reversals in 2014 of previously recognized expenses related to the Company's long-term incentive programs as performance criteria were not achieved. The increase in advertising expenses reflects the Company's increased investments to strengthen our brands, partially offset by a foreign currency exchange impact of 13 percent. The decrease in selling and distribution expenses reflects the impact of acquisitions and divestitures. The decrease in other operating expenses reflects the shift of the Company's marketing spending to more consumer-facing advertising expenses as well as savings from our productivity and reinvestment initiatives. Foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations have a more significant impact on both advertising and other operating expenses as compared to our selling and distribution expenses since they are generally transacted in local currency. Our selling and distribution expenses are primarily related to our Company-owned bottling operations, of which the majority of expenses are attributable to CCR and are primarily denominated in U.S. dollars. Refer to Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information related to acquisitions and divestitures.
In 2016, our pension expense is expected to decrease by $200 million compared to 2015. The anticipated decrease is primarily due to settlement and special termination costs incurred in 2015 of $169 million, the new method to calculate service and interest costs, an increase in the weighted-average discount rate used to calculate the Company's benefit obligations and the impact of $471 million of contributions the Company made in early 2016 to U.S. pension plans. The impact of these items will be partially offset by unfavorable asset performance compared to our expected return during 2015 and a decrease in the expected return on assets for U.S. plans. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position" below for information related to these contributions. Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates — Pension Plan Valuations" above and Note 13 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information related to the pension plan assumptions used by the Company.
As of December 31, 2015, we had $319 million of total unrecognized compensation cost related to nonvested share-based compensation arrangements granted under our plans. This cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 1.8 years as stock-based compensation expense. This expected cost does not include the impact of any future stock-based compensation awards. Refer to Note 12 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
Year Ended December 31, 2014 versus Year Ended December 31, 2013.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle CD=AB/(R+S)\times S}
similar_formula.before: Cost depletion for tax purposes may be completely different from cost depletion for accounting purposes:
similar_formula.after: CD = Cost Depletion.S = Units sold in the current year.R = Reserves on hand at the end of the current year.AB = Adjusted basis of the property at the end of the current year
similar_formula.explanation: Cost Depletion = Adjusted Basis / (Reserves + Units Sold) * Units Sold. This formula calculates the cost depletion for tax purposes, which may differ from cost depletion for accounting purposes. It takes into account the adjusted basis of the property, reserves on hand, and units sold in the current year.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle \textstyle {\mbox{Financial result }}={\mbox{ Interest income}}-{\mbox{ Interest expense}}\pm {\mbox{ Write-downs/write-ups for financial assets}}\pm {\mbox{ Write-downs/write-ups for marketable securities}}+{\mbox{ Other financial income and expenses}}}
similar_formula.before: In mathematical terms financial result is defined as follows:
similar_formula.explanation: Financial Result = Interest Income - Interest Expense ± Write-downs/Write-ups for Financial Assets ± Write-downs/Write-ups for Marketable Securities + Other Financial Income and Expenses. This formula calculates the financial result, which is a measure of a company's financial performance, taking into account interest income and expenses, changes in the value of financial assets and marketable securities, and other financial income and expenses.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Number of Units}}={\frac {\text{Total Fixed Costs}}{\text{Unit Contribution}}}}
similar_formula.before: The quantity, {\displaystyle \left(P-V\right)} , is of interest in its own right, and is called the Unit Contribution Margin (C): it is the marginal profit per unit, or alternatively the portion of each sale that contributes to Fixed Costs. Thus the break-even point can be more simply computed as the point where Total Contribution = Total Fixed Cost:
similar_formula.explanation: Number of Units = Total Fixed Costs / Unit Contribution. This formula calculates the number of units a business needs to sell to cover its fixed costs, using the unit contribution margin (the difference between the unit sale price and the unit variable cost). The unit contribution margin represents the portion of each sale that contributes to covering the fixed costs.

similar_formula.formula: GVA at factor cost = value of output (quantity * price) - value of intermediary consumption.
similar_formula.before: GDP at factor cost = gross value added (GVA) at factor cost.GDP at factor cost = value of the final goods and services produced within the domestic territory of a country during one year by all production units inclusive of depreciation.
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Value Added at factor cost = value of output (quantity * price) - value of intermediate consumption. (Changed 'GVA' to 'Gross Value Added' and 'intermediary' to 'intermediate' for better understanding)

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Break-even(in Sales)}}={\frac {\text{Fixed Costs}}{C/P}}.}
similar_formula.before: To calculate the break-even point in terms of revenue (a.k.a. currency units, a.k.a. sales proceeds) instead of Unit Sales (X), the above calculation can be multiplied by Price, or, equivalently, the Contribution Margin Ratio (Unit Contribution Margin over Price) can be calculated:
similar_formula.after: the Unit Contribution Margin (C): it is the marginal profit per unit, or alternatively the portion of each sale that contributes to Fixed Costs. P is Unit Sale Price
similar_formula.explanation: Break-even (in Sales) = Fixed Costs / (Unit Contribution Margin / Unit Sale Price). This formula calculates the break-even point in terms of sales revenue, which is the amount of sales needed to cover the fixed costs. The unit contribution margin is the difference between the unit sale price and the unit variable cost, representing the portion of each sale that contributes to covering the fixed costs.

similar_formula.formula: Profit and Loss = P*X-(TFC+TVC)
similar_formula.before: Cost-Volume-Profit Analysis (CVP): assuming the linear CVP model, the computation of Profit and Loss ( Net Income ) reduces as follows:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) .where TC = TFC + TVC is Total Cost = Total Fixed Cost + Total Variable Cost and X is Number of Units. Thus Profit is the Contribution Margin times Number of Units, minus the Total Fixed Costs.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit and Loss = (Price * Number of Units) - (Total Fixed Cost + Total Variable Cost); This formula calculates the profit and loss (net income) in cost-volume-profit analysis, where profit and loss is the difference between the total revenue (price times the number of units) and the total cost (total fixed cost plus total variable cost).

similar_formula.formula: Operating profit = gross profit − overheads and other indirect costs
similar_formula.before: Net profit on a P & L (profit and loss) account:
similar_formula.explanation: Operating Profit = Gross Profit − Overheads and Indirect Costs (Operating profit is the income generated after subtracting overheads and other indirect costs from the gross profit.)

similar_formula.formula: Margin of safety% = (current output - breakeven output)/current output × 100
similar_formula.before: Margin of safety represents the strength of the business. It enables a business to know what is the exact amount it has gained or lost and whether they are over or below the break-even point.  In break-even analysis, margin of safety is the extent by which actual or projected sales exceed the break-even sales.
similar_formula.after: When dealing with budgets you would instead replace "Current output" with "Budgeted output." If P/V ratio is given then profit/PV ratio.
similar_formula.explanation: Margin of safety% = (Current production - Breakeven production)/Current production × 100; This formula calculates the percentage of production that is above the breakeven point, indicating the strength of the business.

similar_formula.formula: Cost of sales = Goods available for sale - Closing inventory
similar_formula.explanation: Cost of Sales = (Opening Inventory + Purchases + Freight In) - Closing Inventory

similar_formula.formula: Profit and Loss = TR-TC
similar_formula.before: Cost-Volume-Profit Analysis (CVP): assuming the linear CVP model, the computation of Profit and Loss ( Net Income ) reduces as follows:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) .where TC = TFC + TVC is Total Cost = Total Fixed Cost + Total Variable Cost and X is Number of Units. Thus Profit is the Contribution Margin times Number of Units, minus the Total Fixed Costs.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit and Loss = Total Revenue - Total Cost; This formula calculates the profit and loss (net income) in cost-volume-profit analysis, where profit and loss is the difference between total revenue and total cost (total fixed cost plus total variable cost).

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{DOL}}={\frac {\text{Total Contribution}}{\text{Operating Income}}}={\frac {\text{Total Contribution}}{{\text{Total Contribution}}-{\text{Fixed Costs}}}}={\frac {({\text{P}}-{\text{V}})\cdot {\text{X}}}{({\text{P}}-{\text{V}})\cdot {\text{X}}-{\text{FC}}}}}
similar_formula.before: The Degree of Operating Leverage (DOL) can be computed in a number of equivalent ways;This can also be computed as Total Contribution Margin over Operating Income :
similar_formula.after: The above equivalence follows as the relative change in operating income with one more unit dX equals the contribution margin divided by operating income while the relative change in sales with one more unit dX equals price divided by revenue (or, in other words, 1 / X with X being the quantity).
similar_formula.explanation: DegreeOfOperatingLeverage = \frac{TotalContribution}{OperatingIncome} = \frac{TotalContribution}{TotalContribution - FixedCosts} = \frac{(Price - VariableCost) \cdot Quantity}{(Price - VariableCost) \cdot Quantity - FixedCosts} - The Degree of Operating Leverage (DOL) can also be calculated using the total contribution margin and operating income, which shows the relationship between the contribution margin and fixed costs.

similar_formula.formula: Profit Margin = (Sale price − Cost) / Sale price
similar_formula.before: Below shows markup as a percentage of the cost added to the cost to create a new total (i.e. cost plus).
similar_formula.explanation: Profit Margin = (Selling Price - Cost Price) / Selling Price; This formula calculates the profit margin, which is the difference between the selling price and the cost price divided by the selling price.

similar_formula.formula: Augmented Payout Ratio = (Dividends + Buybacks)/ Net Income for the same period
similar_formula.before: Some companies choose stock buybacks as an alternative to dividends; in such cases this ratio becomes less meaningful. One way to adapt it using an augmented payout ratio:
similar_formula.after: Historic data[edit]
similar_formula.explanation: Augmented Payout Ratio = (Total Dividends + Stock Buybacks) / Net Income for the same period; This formula calculates the percentage of a company's net income that is returned to shareholders through dividends and stock buybacks, providing a more comprehensive view of shareholder returns.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle CD=S/(R+S)\times AB}
similar_formula.before: Cost depletion for tax purposes may be completely different from cost depletion for accounting purposes:
similar_formula.after: CD = Cost Depletion.S = Units sold in the current year.R = Reserves on hand at the end of the current year.AB = Adjusted basis of the property at the end of the current year
similar_formula.explanation: Cost Depletion = Units Sold / (Reserves + Units Sold) * Adjusted Basis. This formula calculates the cost depletion for tax purposes, which may differ from cost depletion for accounting purposes. It takes into account the adjusted basis of the property, reserves on hand, and units sold in the current year.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\frac {C}{P}}={\frac {\text{Unit Contribution Margin}}{\text{Price}}}}
similar_formula.before: The Contribution Margin Ratio is the percentage of Contribution over Total Revenue, which can be calculated from the unit contribution over unit price or total contribution over Total Revenue:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) minus Unit Variable Cost (V):
similar_formula.explanation: Contribution Margin Ratio = Unit Contribution Margin / Price; This formula calculates the percentage of contribution over total revenue, where the contribution margin ratio is the unit contribution margin (unit revenue minus unit variable cost) divided by the unit price.

similar_formula.formula: Net profit = net sales – cost of goods sold – operating expense – taxes – interest
similar_formula.explanation: Net Profit = Net Sales - Cost of Goods Sold - Operating Expenses - Taxes - Interest; Explanation: Net profit is the final profit after deducting all costs and expenses, including cost of goods sold, operating expenses, taxes, and interest, from the net sales. It represents the actual profit earned by a business.

similar_formula.formula: Adj. EBITDA = (Gross Operating Revenue) − (Operating Expenses)
similar_formula.before: DSCR = Net Operating Income / Debt Service
similar_formula.after: Debt Service = (Principal Repayment) + (Interest Payments) + (Lease Payments)
similar_formula.explanation: Adjusted EBITDA = (Total Revenue from Operations) - (Expenses from Operations)

similar_formula.formula: PL=C*X-TFC
similar_formula.before: Thus the Total Variable Costs {\displaystyle {\text{TVC}}=V\times X} offset, and the Net Income (Profit and Loss) is Total Contribution Margin minus Total Fixed Costs:
similar_formula.after: TR=Total Revenue,TC=Total Costs,where C = Unit Contribution (Margin),TC = Total costs. TFC = Total fixed costs. V = Unit variable cost (variable cost per unit). X = Number of units. TR = S = Total revenue = Sales. P = (Unit) sales price.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit = (Contribution per Unit * Number of Units) - Total Fixed Costs. This formula calculates the profit by multiplying the contribution per unit by the number of units sold and then subtracting the total fixed costs.

similar_formula.formula: Retained earnings = opening retained earnings + current year net profit from p&l a/c - dividends paid in current year
similar_formula.before: When total assets are greater than total liabilities, stockholders have a positive equity (positive book value ). Conversely, when total liabilities are greater than total assets, stockholders have a negative stockholders' equity (negative book value) — also sometimes called stockholders' deficit. A stockholders' deficit does not mean that stockholders owe money to the corporation as they own only its net assets and are not accountable for its liabilities , though it is one of the definitions of insolvency . It means that the value of the assets of the company must rise above its liabilities before the stockholders hold positive equity value in the company.
similar_formula.after: Tax implications [ edit ]
similar_formula.explanation: Retained earnings = Opening retained earnings + current year net profit - dividends paid in current year - Retained earnings represent the accumulated profits of a company after paying dividends. It is calculated by adding the opening retained earnings to the current year's net profit and subtracting the dividends paid in the current year.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Net profit}}\ (\$)={\text{Sales revenue}}\ (\$)-{\text{Total costs}}\ (\$)}
similar_formula.before: Net profit measures the fundamental profitability of the business. It is the revenues of the activity less the costs of the activity. The main complication is in more complex businesses when overhead needs to be allocated across divisions of the company. Almost by definition, overheads are costs that cannot be directly tied to any specific product or division. The classic example would be the cost of headquarters staff.
similar_formula.explanation: Net Profit ($) = Sales Revenue ($) - Total Costs ($) - This formula calculates the net profit of a business by subtracting the total costs from the sales revenue.

similar_formula.formula: PL=(C+V)*X-(TFC+V*C)
similar_formula.before: Thus the Total Variable Costs {\displaystyle {\text{TVC}}=V\times X} offset, and the Net Income (Profit and Loss) is Total Contribution Margin minus Total Fixed Costs:
similar_formula.after: TR=Total Revenue,TC=Total Costs,where C = Unit Contribution (Margin),TC = Total costs. TFC = Total fixed costs. V = Unit variable cost (variable cost per unit). X = Number of units. TR = S = Total revenue = Sales. P = (Unit) sales price.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit/Loss = (Unit Contribution + Unit Variable Cost) * Number of Units - (Total Fixed Costs + Unit Variable Cost * Unit Contribution); This formula calculates the profit or loss by subtracting the sum of total fixed costs and the product of unit variable cost and unit contribution from the product of the sum of unit contribution and unit variable cost with the number of units.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Return on sales}}\ (\%)={\frac {{\text{Net profit}}\ (\$)}{{\text{Sales revenue}}\ (\$)}}}
similar_formula.after: Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation, and Amortization (EBITDA) is a very popular measure of financial performance. It is used to assess the 'operating' profit of the business. It is a rough way of calculating how much cash the business is generating and is even sometimes called the 'operating cash flow'. It can be useful because it removes factors that change the view of performance depending upon the accounting and financing policies of the business. Supporters argue it reduces management's ability to change the profits they report by their choice of accounting rules and the way they generate financial backing for the company. This metric excludes from consideration expenses related to decisions such as how to finance the business (debt or equity) and over what period they depreciate fixed assets. EBITDA is typically closer to actual cash flow than is NOPAT . ... EBITDA can be calculated by adding back the costs of interest, depreciation, and amortization charges and any taxes incurred.
similar_formula.explanation: Return on Sales (%) = (Net Profit ($) / Sales Revenue ($)) - This formula calculates the percentage of net profit generated from sales revenue, indicating the efficiency of a business in converting sales into profit.

similar_formula.formula: Operating leverage=(Revenue-Variable Cost)/(Revenue-Variable Cost-Fixed Cost)
similar_formula.before: Accounting leverage has the same definition as in investments.  There are several ways to define operating leverage, the most common.  is:
similar_formula.after: Financial leverage is usually defined   as:
similar_formula.explanation: Operating Leverage = (Sales - Variable Expenses) / (Sales - Variable Expenses - Fixed Expenses); This formula calculates the proportion of fixed costs in a company's cost structure, which affects its profitability. A higher operating leverage indicates a higher proportion of fixed costs, making the company more sensitive to changes in sales.

similar_formula.formula: TATA = (Income from Continuing Operationst - Cash Flows from Operationst) / Total Assetst
similar_formula.before: Total Accruals to Total Assets (TATA)
similar_formula.explanation: Total Accruals to Total Assets = (Income from Continuing Operations - Cash Flows from Operations) / Total Assets; This formula calculates the ratio of total accruals to total assets, which is an indicator of a company's financial performance and stability.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Unit margin}}(\$)={\text{Selling price per unit}}(\$)-{\text{Cost per unit}}(\$)}
similar_formula.before: Two related metrics are unit margin and margin percent:
similar_formula.after: "Percentage margins can also be calculated using total sales revenue and total costs. When working with either percentage or unit margins, marketers can perform a simple check by verifying that the individual parts sum to the total."
similar_formula.explanation: Unit Margin ($) = Selling Price per Unit ($) - Cost per Unit ($); The Unit Margin is a financial metric that measures the profit generated from each unit sold by comparing the selling price per unit to the cost per unit. A higher Unit Margin indicates that the company is generating more profit from each unit sold.

similar_formula.formula: Continuing operations formula Earnings per share = (income from continuing operations − preferred dividends) / weighted average common shares
similar_formula.before: Preferred stock rights have precedence over common stock. Therefore, dividends on preferred shares are subtracted before calculating the EPS. When preferred shares are cumulative (i.e. dividends accumulate as payable if unpaid in the given accounting year), annual dividends are deducted whether or not they have been declared. Dividends in arrears are not relevant when calculating EPS.
similar_formula.explanation: Continuing Operations EPS = (Income from Continuing Operations - Preferred Dividends) / Weighted Average Common Shares; Continuing Operations EPS is a financial metric that measures the portion of a company's profit from ongoing business activities allocated to each outstanding share of common stock. It is calculated by subtracting preferred dividends from income from continuing operations and dividing the result by the weighted average number of common shares outstanding.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Net Sales}}={\text{Revenue}}-{\text{Cost of Sales Returns}}-{\text{Allowances and Discounts}}}
similar_formula.before: Gross Profit Margin is calculated as gross profit divided by net sales (percentage). Gross Profit is calculated by deducting the cost of goods sold (COGS) from the revenue, that is all the direct costs. This margin compares revenue to variable cost . It is calculated as:
similar_formula.explanation: Net Sales = Total Revenue - Sales Returns - Discounts and Allowances; This formula calculates the net sales by subtracting the cost of sales returns, allowances, and discounts from the total revenue.

similar_formula.formula: Profit and Loss = C*X-TFC
similar_formula.before: Cost-Volume-Profit Analysis (CVP): assuming the linear CVP model, the computation of Profit and Loss ( Net Income ) reduces as follows:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) .where TC = TFC + TVC is Total Cost = Total Fixed Cost + Total Variable Cost and X is Number of Units. Thus Profit is the Contribution Margin times Number of Units, minus the Total Fixed Costs.
similar_formula.explanation: Net Income = (Unit Contribution * Number of Units) - Total Fixed Costs. In this formula, Net Income represents the profit or loss, Unit Contribution is the revenue per unit minus the variable cost per unit, and Total Fixed Costs are the costs that do not change with the production volume.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{New average rate}}={\frac {{\text{Total balance in company currency }}+{\text{new funds in company currency}}}{{\text{Total balance in voucher currency }}+{\text{new funds in voucher currency}}}}}
similar_formula.before: The calculation is based on the total balances in company and voucher currency and the newly received funds. The following formula is used:
similar_formula.explanation: New average rate = (Total balance in company currency + new funds in company currency) / (Total balance in voucher currency + new funds in voucher currency); The new average rate is calculated based on the total balances in company and voucher currencies and the newly received funds.

similar_formula.formula: return on investment = (revenue − cost of goods sold) / cost of goods sold
similar_formula.before: For a single-period review, divide the return (net profit) by the resources that were committed (investment):
similar_formula.explanation: ROI = (Revenue - COGS) / COGS; This formula calculates the return on investment by dividing the difference between revenue and cost of goods sold by the cost of goods sold.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\frac {C}{P}}={\frac {P-V}{P}}}
similar_formula.before: The Contribution Margin Ratio is the percentage of Contribution over Total Revenue, which can be calculated from the unit contribution over unit price or total contribution over Total Revenue:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) minus Unit Variable Cost (V):
similar_formula.explanation: Contribution Margin Ratio = (Price - Unit Variable Cost) / Price; This formula calculates the percentage of contribution over total revenue, where the contribution margin ratio is the unit contribution margin (unit revenue minus unit variable cost) divided by the unit price.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Contribution Margin Ratio}}=({\text{Sales - Variable Costs}})/{\text{Sales}}}
similar_formula.before: The contribution margin can also be expressed as a percentage. The contribution margin ratio, which is sometimes called the profit-volume ratio, indicates the percentage of each sales dollar available to cover fixed costs and to provide operating revenue. For the company Fusion, Inc. the contribution margin ratio is 40%, which is computed as follows:
similar_formula.after: The contribution margin ratio measures the effect on operating income of an increase or a decrease in sales volume. For example, assume that the management of Fusion, Inc. is studying the effect of adding $80,000 in sales orders. Multiplying the contribution margin ratio (40%) by the change in sales volume ($80,000) indicates that operating income will increase $32,000 if additional orders are obtained. To validate this analysis the table below shows the income statement of the company including additional orders:
similar_formula.explanation: Contribution Margin Ratio = (Revenue - Variable Costs) / Revenue

similar_formula.formula: DAC amortization rate = [present value of DAE + accumulated value of DAC]/[present value of estimated gross profits (EGPs) + accumulated value of actual gross profits (AGPs)]
similar_formula.before: Also referred to as KDAC, the K-factor is basically the percentage of gross profits required to provide for deferred policy acquisition costs. KDAC is
similar_formula.after: The K-factor can change from year to year due to:The true-up process (replacement of expected values by realized values, i.e. actual historical gross profits (AGP) replace prior EGPs).The dynamical unlocking (replacement of assumptions by experience for the projections of future years)
similar_formula.explanation: DAC Amortization Rate = (Present Value of Deferred Acquisition Expenses + Accumulated Value of Deferred Acquisition Costs) / (Present Value of Estimated Gross Profits + Accumulated Value of Actual Gross Profits); This formula calculates the rate at which deferred acquisition costs are amortized, taking into account both estimated and actual gross profits.

similar_formula.formula: PL=TR-TC=(C+V)*X-(TFC+V*C)=C*X-TFC=TCM-TFC
similar_formula.before: Thus the Total Variable Costs {\displaystyle {\text{TVC}}=V\times X} offset, and the Net Income (Profit and Loss) is Total Contribution Margin minus Total Fixed Costs:
similar_formula.after: TR=Total Revenue,TC=Total Costs,where C = Unit Contribution (Margin),TC = Total costs. TFC = Total fixed costs. V = Unit variable cost (variable cost per unit). X = Number of units. TR = S = Total revenue = Sales. P = (Unit) sales price.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit/Loss = Total Revenue - Total Costs = (Unit Contribution + Unit Variable Cost) * Number of Units - (Total Fixed Costs + Unit Variable Cost * Unit Contribution) = (Unit Contribution * Number of Units) - Total Fixed Costs = Total Contribution Margin - Total Fixed Costs; This formula calculates the profit or loss by subtracting total costs from total revenue, which can be expressed in different ways using unit contribution, unit variable cost, number of units, total fixed costs, and total contribution margin.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\frac {\text{Operating Income}}{\text{Sales}}}={\frac {{\text{Unit Price}}-{\text{Unit Variable Cost}}}{\text{Unit Price}}}}
similar_formula.before: If a company has no fixed costs (and hence breaks even at zero), then its DOL equals 1: a 10% increase in Sales yields a 10% increase in Operating Income, and its operating margin equals its contribution margin :
similar_formula.after: DOL is highest near the break-even point ; in fact, at the break-even point, DOL is undefined, because it is infinite: an increase of 10% in sales, say, increases Operating Income for 0 to some positive number (say, $10 ), which is an infinite (or undefined) percentage change; in terms of margins, its Operating Margin is zero, so its DOL is undefined. Similarly, for a very small positive Operating Income (say, $.1 ), a 10% increase in sales may increase Operating Income to $10 , a 100x (or 9,900%) increase, for a DOL of 990; in terms of margins, its Operating Margin is very small, so its DOL is very large.
similar_formula.explanation: Operating Income / Sales = (Unit Price - Unit Variable Cost) / Unit Price. This formula calculates the operating margin, which represents the proportion of a company's revenue that is left after covering variable costs. The higher the operating margin, the more profitable the company is.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\frac {C}{P}}={\frac {\text{Total Contribution Margin}}{\text{Total Revenue}}}}
similar_formula.before: The Contribution Margin Ratio is the percentage of Contribution over Total Revenue, which can be calculated from the unit contribution over unit price or total contribution over Total Revenue:
similar_formula.after: The Unit Contribution Margin (C) is Unit Revenue (Price, P) minus Unit Variable Cost (V):
similar_formula.explanation: Contribution Margin Ratio = Total Contribution Margin / Total Revenue; This formula calculates the percentage of contribution over total revenue, where the contribution margin ratio is the total contribution margin (total revenue minus total variable cost) divided by the total revenue.

similar_formula.formula: Operating profit = gross profit – total operating expenses
similar_formula.explanation: Operating Profit = Gross Profit - Total Operating Expenses; Explanation: Operating profit is the difference between the gross profit and the total operating expenses. It represents the profit generated from the core operations of a business, excluding any non-operating income or expenses.

similar_formula.formula: Gross profit = sales revenue − cost of sales and other direct costs
similar_formula.before: Net profit on a P & L (profit and loss) account:
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Profit = Sales Revenue − Cost of Sales and Direct Costs (Gross profit is the income generated after subtracting the cost of sales and other direct costs from the sales revenue.)

similar_formula.formula: Sales = Sales for the year - Returns in (Goods that were returned to the entity during the course of the year)
similar_formula.before: Sales calculation:
similar_formula.explanation: Sales = Annual Sales - Returned Goods

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Profit Margin}}={{100\cdot ({\text{Sales}}-{\text{Total Expenses}})} \over {\text{Revenue}}}}
similar_formula.before: Profit margin is a measure of profitability . It is calculated by finding the profit as a percentage of the revenue .
similar_formula.explanation: Profit Margin = (100 * (Sales - Total Expenses)) / Revenue. This formula calculates the percentage of profit a company makes from its total revenue after deducting all expenses. A higher profit margin indicates a more profitable company.

similar_formula.formula: PL=TCM-TFC
similar_formula.before: Thus the Total Variable Costs {\displaystyle {\text{TVC}}=V\times X} offset, and the Net Income (Profit and Loss) is Total Contribution Margin minus Total Fixed Costs:
similar_formula.after: TR=Total Revenue,TC=Total Costs,where C = Unit Contribution (Margin),TC = Total costs. TFC = Total fixed costs. V = Unit variable cost (variable cost per unit). X = Number of units. TR = S = Total revenue = Sales. P = (Unit) sales price.
similar_formula.explanation: Profit/Loss = Total Contribution Margin - Total Fixed Costs; This formula calculates the profit or loss by subtracting total fixed costs from the total contribution margin.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Gross Profit Margin}}={100\cdot {\text{Gross Profit}} \over {\text{Net Sales}}}}
similar_formula.before: Gross Profit Margin is calculated as gross profit divided by net sales (percentage). Gross Profit is calculated by deducting the cost of goods sold (COGS) from the revenue, that is all the direct costs. This margin compares revenue to variable cost . It is calculated as:
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Profit Margin (%) = 100 * (Gross Profit / Net Sales); This formula calculates the gross profit margin as a percentage by dividing the gross profit by the net sales and multiplying by 100.

similar_formula.formula: Combined Profit Volume Ratio = Combined Contribution/Combined Sale * 100
similar_formula.before: Combined Profit Volume Ratio can be calculated by using following formula
similar_formula.explanation: Combined Profit Volume Ratio = (Combined Contribution / Combined Sales) * 100. This formula calculates the combined profit volume ratio by dividing the combined contribution by the combined sales and then multiplying by 100 to get the percentage.

similar_formula.formula: GCI (Gross cash invested) = (Gross tangible and intangible assets before depreciation or write-offs) + (investments in associates) + (working capital)
similar_formula.before: EV/GCI ( enterprise value /gross cash invested) is an advanced valuation multiple used to compare a company's book value of its assets to their current market value. The ratio is similar to P/B ratio, but EV/GCI is calculated on an EV-basis, taking into account all the company's security-holders.
similar_formula.after: When EV/GCI is higher than 1, then the market is willing to pay a valuation premium. A discount takes place in the opposite case.
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Cash Invested = (Gross Tangible and Intangible Assets before Depreciation or Write-offs) + (Investments in Associates) + (Working Capital). This formula calculates the total amount of cash invested in a company, including its tangible and intangible assets, investments in associates, and working capital.

similar_formula.formula: earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) = Sales (revenue) – cost of goods sold– selling, general, administrative expenses (SGA)– depreciation/ amortization
similar_formula.before: The net profit or loss is determined by:
similar_formula.explanation: EBIT = Revenue - Cost of Goods Sold - Selling, General, and Administrative Expenses - Depreciation/Amortization; This formula calculates the earnings before interest and taxes by subtracting the cost of goods sold, selling, general, and administrative expenses, and depreciation/amortization from the revenue.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Gross Profit}}={\text{Revenue}}-({\text{Direct materials}}+{\text{Direct labor}}+{\text{Factory overhead}})}
similar_formula.before: Gross Profit Margin is calculated as gross profit divided by net sales (percentage). Gross Profit is calculated by deducting the cost of goods sold (COGS) from the revenue, that is all the direct costs. This margin compares revenue to variable cost . It is calculated as:
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Profit = Revenue - (Direct Materials + Direct Labor + Factory Overhead). This formula calculates the gross profit a company makes by subtracting the cost of goods sold (COGS) from its total revenue. A higher gross profit indicates a more profitable company.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{gross margin}}={\frac {\text{markup}}{1+{\text{markup}}}}}
similar_formula.before: Converting markup to gross margin
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Margin = Markup / (1 + Markup); The Gross Margin is a financial metric that measures the profitability of a company by comparing its markup (the difference between the cost of a product and its selling price) to the total cost of the product. A higher Gross Margin indicates a more profitable company.

similar_formula.formula: GMI = [(Salest-1 - COGSt-1) / Salest-1] / [(Salest - COGSt) / Salest]
similar_formula.before: Gross Margin Index (GMI)
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Margin Index (GMI) = [(Sales in Year T-1 - Cost of Goods Sold in Year T-1) / Sales in Year T-1] / [(Sales in Year T - Cost of Goods Sold in Year T) / Sales in Year T]; The GMI is a financial ratio that measures the change in a company's gross margin over time. A lower GMI indicates a potential decline in profitability.

similar_formula.formula: SGAI = (SG&A Expenset / Salest) / (SG&A Expenset-1 / Salest-1)
similar_formula.before: Sales General and Administrative Expenses Index (SGAI)
similar_formula.explanation: Sales General and Administrative Expenses Index = (Current Year SG&A Expenses / Current Year Sales) / (Previous Year SG&A Expenses / Previous Year Sales) - This formula calculates the Sales General and Administrative Expenses Index, which measures the change in a company's SG&A expenses relative to its sales.

similar_formula.formula: {\displaystyle {\text{Gross margin percentage}}={\frac {{\text{Revenue}}-{\text{COGS}}}{\text{Revenue}}}\times 100\%}
similar_formula.before: or as the ratio of gross profit to revenue, usually as a percentage:
similar_formula.after: Cost of sales, also denominated "cost of goods sold" (COGS), includes variable costs and fixed costs directly related to the sale, e.g., material costs, labor, supplier profit, shipping-in costs (cost of transporting the product to the point of sale, as opposed to shipping-out costs which are not included in COGS), etc. It excludes indirect fixed costs, e.g., office expenses, rent, and administrative costs.
similar_formula.explanation: Gross Margin Percentage = (Revenue - Cost of Goods Sold) / Revenue x 100%; The Gross Margin Percentage is a financial metric that measures the profitability of a company by comparing its revenue to its cost of goods sold (COGS). It represents the percentage of revenue that remains after accounting for the direct costs associated with producing and selling the goods. A higher Gross Margin Percentage indicates a more profitable company.

html_string: Year Ended December 31, 2014 versus Year Ended December 31, 2013

Our gross profit margin increased to 61.1 percent in 2014 from 60.7 percent in 2013. The increase was partially due to the deconsolidation of our Brazilian bottling operations in July 2013 as well as lower commodity costs, primarily in our North America finished goods business, and favorable geographic mix. Refer to Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information regarding the impact of the deconsolidation of our Brazilian bottling operations.

The favorable geographic mix was primarily due to growth in emerging markets. Although this shift in geographic mix has a negative impact on net operating revenues, it generally has a favorable impact on our gross profit margin due to the correlated impact it has on our product mix. The product mix in the majority of our emerging and developing markets is more heavily skewed toward our sparkling beverage products, which generally yield a higher gross profit margin compared to our still beverages and finished products.
Selling, General and Administrative Expenses
The following table sets forth the significant components of selling, general and administrative expenses (in millions):

Year Ended December 31, 2015 2014 2013
Stock-based compensation expense $236 $209 $227
Advertising expenses 3,976 3,499 3,266
Selling and distribution expenses 6,025 6,412 6,419
Other operating expenses 6,190 7,098 7,398
Selling, general and administrative expenses $16,427 $17,218 $17,310
Year Ended December 31, 2015 versus Year Ended December 31, 2014

Selling, general and administrative expenses decreased $791 million, or 5 percent. During the year ended December 31, 2015, fluctuations in foreign currency decreased selling, general and administrative expenses by 6 percent. The increase in stock-based compensation was primarily due to reversals in 2014 of previously recognized expenses related to the Company's long-term incentive programs as performance criteria were not achieved. The increase in advertising expenses reflects the Company's increased investments to strengthen our brands, partially offset by a foreign currency exchange impact of 13 percent. The decrease in selling and distribution expenses reflects the impact of acquisitions and divestitures. The decrease in other operating expenses reflects the shift of the Company's marketing spending to more consumer-facing advertising expenses as well as savings from our productivity and reinvestment initiatives. Foreign currency exchange rate fluctuations have a more significant impact on both advertising and other operating expenses as compared to our selling and distribution expenses since they are generally transacted in local currency. Our selling and distribution expenses are primarily related to our Company-owned bottling operations, of which the majority of expenses are attributable to CCR and are primarily denominated in U.S. dollars. Refer to Note 2 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information related to acquisitions and divestitures.

In 2016, our pension expense is expected to decrease by $200 million compared to 2015. The anticipated decrease is primarily due to settlement and special termination costs incurred in 2015 of $169 million, the new method to calculate service and interest costs, an increase in the weighted-average discount rate used to calculate the Company's benefit obligations and the impact of $471 million of contributions the Company made in early 2016 to U.S. pension plans. The impact of these items will be partially offset by unfavorable asset performance compared to our expected return during 2015 and a decrease in the expected return on assets for U.S. plans. Refer to the heading "Liquidity, Capital Resources and Financial Position" below for information related to these contributions. Refer to the heading "Critical Accounting Policies and Estimates — Pension Plan Valuations" above and Note 13 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements for additional information related to the pension plan assumptions used by the Company.

As of December 31, 2015, we had $319 million of total unrecognized compensation cost related to nonvested share-based compensation arrangements granted under our plans. This cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 1.8 years as stock-based compensation expense. This expected cost does not include the impact of any future stock-based compensation awards. Refer to Note 12 of Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
Year Ended December 31, 2014 versus Year Ended December 31, 2013
qa:
Question 1: What is the Operating Profit Margin for the year 2015?
Answer 1: Using the formula <Operating Profit Margin = (Operating Profit / Total Revenue) x 100>, we need to know the Operating Profit and Total Revenue for 2015 to calculate the Operating Profit Margin.

Question 2: What is the Change in Net Working Capital between 2014 and 2015?
Answer 2: Using the formula <Change in Net Working Capital = Net Working Capital in 2015 - Net Working Capital in 2014>, we need to know the Net Working Capital for both years to calculate the change.

Question 3: What is the Return on Investment (ROI) for the year 2015?
Answer 3: Using the formula <ROI = (Net Profit / Cost of Investment) x 100>, we need to know the Net Profit and Cost of Investment for 2015 to calculate the ROI.

Question 4: What is the Debt to Equity Ratio for the year 2015?
Answer 4: Using the formula <Debt to Equity Ratio = Total Liabilities / Shareholders' Equity>, we need to know the Total Liabilities and Shareholders' Equity for 2015 to calculate the Debt to Equity Ratio.

Question 5: What is the Earnings Before Interest and Taxes (EBIT) for the year 2015?
Answer 5: Using the formula <EBIT = Net Income + Interest + Taxes>, we need to know the Net Income, Interest, and Taxes for 2015 to calculate the EBIT.

As of December 31, 2022 and 2021, cash and cash equivalents of $1.7 billion and $3.0 billion, respectively, included money market and other short-term funds of approximately $341 million and $816 million, respectively, which are considered Level 2 in the fair value hierarchy.
For assets that are measured using quoted prices in active markets, the fair value is the published market price per unit multiplied by the number of units held, without consideration of transaction costs. The majority of the derivatives entered into by us are valued using internal valuation techniques as no quoted market prices exist for such instruments. The principal techniques used to value these instruments are discounted cash flow and Black-Scholes models. The key inputs, which are considered observable and vary depending on the type of derivative, include contractual terms, interest rate yield curves, foreign exchange rates and volatility.
Available-for-sale debt securities, which consist of convertible debt and convertible redeemable preferred shares issued by nonpublic entities, are measured using discounted cash flow and option pricing models. Those available-for-sale debt securities are classified as Level 3 fair value measurements when there are no observable transactions near the balance sheet date due to the lack of observable data over certain fair value inputs such as equity volatility. The fair values of available-for-sale debt securities increase when interest rates decrease, equity volatility increases, or the fair values of the equity shares underlying the conversion options increase.
Contingent payments related to acquisitions, which consist of milestone payments and sales-based payments, are valued using discounted cash flow techniques. The fair value of milestone payments reflects management’s expectations of probability of payment, and increases as the probability of payment increases or the expected timing of payments is accelerated. The fair value of sales-based payments is based upon probability-weighted future.
revenue estimates, and increases as revenue estimates increase, probability weighting of higher revenue scenarios increases or the expected timing of payment is accelerated.

For assets that are measured using quoted prices in active markets, the fair value is the published market price per unit multiplied by the number of units held, without consideration of transaction costs.
